elements.content: The construction of low-cost, highly efficient, and stable electrocatalysts is a significant challenge for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Herein, we report a facile strategy to fabricate ultrathin metal–organic framework (MOF) nanosheet arrays doped with two rare-earth elements, Y and Ce, and self-supported on nickel foam (NF) to enhance the HER and OER performance by constructing abundant active sites and bimetallic synergistic effects. The NiYCe-MOF/NF features an ultrathin nanosheet array structure and is uniformly and richly codoped by Y and Ce. When it was explored as both the anode and cathode electrocatalysts for overall water splitting, it achieved 10 mA cm–2 at 136 and 245 mV for the HER and OER in an alkaline electrolyte, respectively. Notably, an extremely low cell voltage of 1.54 V was required to achieve 100 mA cm–2 in 1.0 M KOH solution, making it a promising substitute for noble-metal catalysts.

The NiYCe-MOF/NF features an ultrathin nanosheet array structure and is uniformly and richly codoped by Y and Ce. When it was explored as both the anode and cathode electrocatalysts for overall water splitting, it achieved 10 mA cm-2 at 136 and 245 mV for the HER and OER in an alkaline electrolyte, respectively. Notably, an extremely low cell voltage of 1.54 V was required to achieve 100 mA cm-2 in 1.0 M KOH solution, making it a promising substitute for noble-metal catalysts.

elements.content: The development of sustainable and environmentally friendly energy technologies is a critical issue in addressing limited fossil resources and rapidly growing energy demand. Hydrogen is an ideal substitute for fossil fuel, offering the advantages of high energy density and net-zero carbon emissions. This is an efficient and practical method for producing hydrogen via water electrolysis, in which both the HER and OER play a pivotal role in the interconversion process of electrical and chemical energy. However, the sluggish kinetics and constricted electron transfer rate severely hinder the development of overall water splitting. Therefore, designing efficient electrocatalysts employed to reduce the reaction barrier and optimize the electron transfer pathway is of great significance. At present, noble-metal Pt-/Ru-based catalysts exhibit remarkable electrocatalytic activity for the HER and OER, respectively; however, their large-scale application is hindered by the scarcity and high price. Therefore, the development of low-cost, highly efficient, stable bifunctional electrocatalysts is the key to the practical industrial applications of overall water splitting.

elements.content: Recently, MOFs have attracted great attention as novel electrocatalytic material platforms due to their large surface area and tunable pore structures. However, the catalytic activity for overall water splitting is limited by the lack of effective active sites. Heteroatom doping, especially the introduction of strongly charged atoms, is an effective way to promote electrocatalytic activity, which can accelerate the adsorption of H+ and further generate H2 on the surface via the formation of additional active centers. Moreover, MOF catalysts doped by heteroatoms exhibit an excellent electrocatalytic overall water splitting performance due to the optimized electronic structure and increased functional heterojunctions for the HER and OER.

elements.content: Among the numerous strategies, cation engineering is a remarkably effective way to regulate the electronic structure of catalysts and to optimize the adsorption/desorption energy barriers of intermediates. In addition, the increased active sites facilitate conductivity and further enhance catalytic activity. Yan’s group reported that the catalytic activity of the OER was significantly enhanced by doping with transition-metal atoms. This result reveals that the introduction of positively charged transition-metal atoms in the lattice can tune the electronic structure, optimizing ΔG* and conductivity. Meanwhile, Li’s group adopted a cation-doping strategy for the single-phase catalyst, which effectively improved the HER activity due to the moderate electron density. In comparison with 3d transition metals, rare-earth elements with unique 4f electrons (e.g., Ce, Pr, Y, etc.) have been demonstrated to improve the catalytic efficiency when they are combined with other active sites. What is more, Ce-induced compounds have mixed electronic/ionic conductivity due to the redox interaction between Ce3+ and Ce4+. Dai’s group reported a Co3O4/CeO2 nanohybrid with abundant oxygen vacancies, exhibiting improved OER activity. Tang’s group designed a thin CoS@CeO x layer structure to prevent corrosion and affect Co2+/Co3+ in CoS, which improved the OER durability. On the other hand, Y-related materials have attracted significant attention due to their enhanced electron capture capability, hindering the growth of crystals where metal ions can trap photoexcited electrons during photoelectrochemical water splitting. However, the synthesis of multielement hybrid catalysts remains a challenge and has rarely been reported. Thus, researchers have striven to identify the active sites for the HER and OER to tailor highly active water electrolysis catalysts. The most common strategies, such as high-temperature calcination, may sacrifice intrinsic metal active sites and limit the bulk conductivity. Two-dimensional (2D) MOF-derived materials have been reported with little effort made to increase the microstructure, conductivity, or catalytic centers. Therefore, it seems crucial to optimize the structure and active sites of MOF-derived materials to improve electrocatalytic performance.

elements.content: Herein, we report the synthesis of Y- and Ce-doped ultrathin MOF nanosheet array electrocatalysts by a simple hydrothermal method using Ni-MOF as a template. The obtained NiYCe-MOF/NF was employed as a bifunctional electrocatalyst to explore the overall water splitting. In particular, the structural characterizations verified that the doping of rare-earth atoms at the Ni sites induced electron transfer to the Ni sites. Benefiting from the unique electronic and structural features of the constructed catalyst, the resulting NiYCe-MOF/NF showed excellent electrochemical HER and OER activities with overpotentials of 136 and 245 mV at 10 mA cm–2, respectively, which are significantly better than those of previously reported Ni-MOF-based catalysts.

elements.content: NiYCe-MOF/NF nanosheet arrays with different Y and Ce contents were prepared by regulating the Y/Ce molar ratio, and a schematic diagram is shown in a. Similar procedures were used for the synthesis of Ni-MOF, NiY-MOF, and NiCe-MOF control samples with different raw materials. The SEM images (b,c) show that the morphology of NiYCe-MOF/NF featured ultrathin nanosheet arrays supported on the NF, while pure Ni-MOF without the NF substrate presented a stacked-sheet structure (Figure S1). NiYCe-MOF was further confirmed by TEM (d), indicating a flakelike structure without any agglomeration. The elemental mapping images (e) suggest that the elements C, O, Ni, Y, and Ce were uniformly distributed over the nanosheets. The HR-TEM image of NiYCe-MOF in f shows some clear lattice fringes with a spacing of 1.4 nm; moreover, the polycrystalline properties were confirmed by a selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern with clearly concentric circular rings in the inset. The crystal lattice and electronic structure of NiYCe-MOF were investigated by inverse fast Fourier transform (FFT), as shown in g; it was found that the introduction of rare-earth atoms produced lattice distortions, which may be caused by partial replacement of local Ni atoms with Y and Ce atoms. The details of the control experiments for details can be seen in Figures S2–S10 in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: a shows that the peaks at 3455, 1600, 1404, and 786 cm–1 can be attributed to the stretching vibrations of hydroxyl, benzene carbon, phenolic carbon, and hydrocarbons, respectively. The wavenumber changes introduced by metal elements were usually associated with various bonds. Apparently, a distinct wave of O–Ce bonding at 583 cm–1 was observed for NiCe-MOF and NiYCe-MOF, confirming the successful formation of ionic bonds between the metal and oxygen-containing species, and the vibration peak of Ni–O was also observed at 488 cm–1. The XRD spectrum of the Ni substrate in Figure S11 shows that the diffraction peaks can be attributed to metallic nickel (JCPDS: 04-0850), and it can be found that the main peaks of NiYCe-MOF were shown in NiYCe-MOF/NF while the weak diffraction peaks were relatively slight. The nanosheet structure can also be detected by SAXS, as shown in b. An intense diffraction peak at 0.75° corresponded to an apparent distance (d spacing) of 1.4 nm, which was consistent with the HR-TEM image analysis results (f). To evaluate the orientation of crystals grown after the introduction of Y and Ce, 2D SAXS patterns were employed as shown in c. The 2D SAXS patterns of Ni-MOF and NiY-MOF show the transition from bright field to dark field in the innermost circle, implying a good orientation of the crystals during the growth process. Further introduction of Ce may alter the crystal growth, and the 2D SAXS patterns of NiCe-MOF and NiYCe-MOF demonstrate a similar orientation of the nanosheet structure under hydrothermal conditions. Meanwhile, a diffuse diffraction ring appeared in the low-angle region, implying the inhibition of the isotropic phase. The above analysis results suggested that the introduction of Ce can be well regulated in MOF materials by creating additional active sites to achieve tailored catalytic performance. The elemental composition and chemical state were investigated by XPS analysis. The successful introduction of Y and Ce into Ni-MOF was confirmed by comparison with the survey XPS profiles of Ni-MOF and NiYCe-MOF (Figure S12). The high-resolution XPS spectra of Ni, O, Y, and Ce in the NiYCe-MOF sample were fitted using the Gaussian method. d shows the Ni 2p spectra, where the peaks of NiYCe-MOF located at ∼856.8 and ∼874.3 eV were assigned to the spin–orbit doublets of Ni 3d1/2 and Ni 3d3/2, respectively. Furthermore, two other satellite peaks were observed at 861.3 and 879.7 eV. In the high-resolution XPS spectra in the O 1s regions of Ni-MOF, the two main peaks located at 530.5 and 531.5 eV can be attributed to the lattice oxygen species (O2–) and chemisorbed oxygen species, respectively (e). Moreover, in these spectral images, the peaks of lattice oxygen species of NiYCe-MOF were divided into Ce–O (530.3 eV) and Y–O (532.3 eV) peaks. In general, the increase in the area of the metal–oxygen peak due to the adsorption of hydroxyl groups on the surface can further prove the growth of active centers after doping. f displays the high-resolution XPS spectrum of NiYCe-MOF in the Y 3d region, which can be fitted with two peaks attributed to Y 3d5/2 (157.8 eV) and Y 3d3/2 (159.8 eV). Additionally, the characteristic peaks of Ce were also fitted; the peaks located at 885.3 and 903.7 eV were ascribed to Ce 3d5/2 and Ce 3d3/2, respectively, indicating the coexistence of Ce3+ and Ce4+ in the NiYCe-MOF, which may lead to a charge imbalance.

elements.content: XANES and EXAFS were measured to further explore the chemical states of typical Ni-MOF and NiYCe-MOF using Ni foil, NiO, and Ni­(OH)2 as references. As shown in a, the peaks of the samples located at approximately 8349 eV in the pre-edge region can be attributed to the dipole-forbidden but quadrupole-allowed transition from 1s to 3d, which were equivalent to the NiO benchmark. The positions of the rising edges of the samples compared to the reference value of the Ni foil indicated that the oxidation state of Ni was between Ni0 and NiII. Meanwhile, the rising-edge positions of Ni-MOF were negatively shifted compared to those of NiO, while NiYCe-MOF showed a similar trend. This phenomenon indicated that some electrons were transferred to the site of Ni after the introduction of Y and Ce, which may be due to the rearrangement of electron distribution caused by the interaction of Ni with rare-earth elements. As presented in b, the FT-EXAFS intensities of all the corresponding peaks for the NiYCe-MOF were decreased relative to those of Ni foil, NiO, Ni­(OH)2, and Ni-MOF control samples, indicating an increase in the coordination number of the Ni atoms. The EXAFS spectra of Ni-MOF and NiYCe-MOF showed a main peak at 1.62 Å, corresponding to Ni–O coordination, which indicated that Ni ions were dominant in the oxidation state. The above results showed that the coordination number of the Ni–O shell remained nearly constant after Y and Ce codoping, suggesting a well-preserved stability structure. At the same time, the maximum intensities of Ni states in the WT contour map of Ni-MOF and NiYCe-MOF were also significantly different from those of Ni foil and NiO (c–f), suggesting that the Y and Ce heteroatoms were successfully doped into the Ni-MOF matrix. g shows that NiYCe-MOF exhibited a highly abundant porous structure along with the highest absorption capacity, resulting in the highest specific surface area (124.6 m2/g); additionally, the specific surface areas of Ni-MOF, NiCe-MOF, and NiYCe-MOF were 106.4, 112.0, and 94.2 m2/g, respectively (Figure S13). In addition, the porous structure of NiYCe-MOF further exhibited a hierarchical porous size, extending from nanometers to sub-micrometers, with an average pore size of 30 nm (see the inset in g). These results indicated that NiYCe-MOF contained a substantial number of mesopores, which favored the mass transfer process.

elements.content: The electrocatalytic performances of the samples were evaluated in 1.0 M KOH solution with a typical system of commercial Pt/C (20 wt %) and RuO2 catalysts as benchmarks. The quantitative analysis data of doping elements and the amounts of catalyst loadings are detailed in Figured S14–S16 in the Supporting Information. A representative LSV test (a) shows that NiYCe-MOF/NF exhibited superior OER activity compared with Ni-MOF/NF, NiY-MOF/NF, and NiCe-MOF/NF. Even the OER performance of NiYCe-MOF/NF is significantly better than that of commercial RuO2. Likewise, the line-fitting Tafel plot of 65 mV dec–1 for NiYCe-MOF/NF in b was lower than those of Ni-MOF/NF, NiY-MOF/NF, NiCe-MOF/NF, and commercial RuO2, indicating the more effective reaction kinetics of NiYCe-MOF/NF for the OER. As shown in c, a chronopotentiometric test was employed to estimate the stability of NiYCe-MOF/NF. The retention rate of the initial catalytic activity can reach 94% after 100 h at 100 mA cm–2, while NiYCe-MOF/NF a suffered slight performance degradation (10%) at 200 mA cm–2. The above analysis results illustrated that NiYCe-MOF/NF possessed excellent stability in the long-term OER operation process. As shown in Figure S17, the EIS of the samples showed that NiYCe-MOF/NF exhibited a small polarization resistance and demonstrated faster catalytic kinetics and an enhanced electron transfer rate relative to Ni-MOF/NF, NiY-MOF/NF, and NiCe-MOF/NF due to the abundant active catalytic sites and the synergistic effect between different metal centers. In addition, the electrochemical active surface areas (ECSAs) were also calculated by measuring the Cdl values from CV curves (d and Figure S18). NiYCe-MOF/NF exhibited a Cdl value of nearly 36.5 mF cm–2, higher than those of Ni-MOF/NF (4.1 mF cm–2), NiY-MOF/NF (25.9 mF cm–2) and NiCe-MOF/NF electrodes (29.8 mF cm–2), indicating that NiYCe-MOF/NF was equipped with more active sites. The mass activity (the current density normalized to the mass) of NiYCe-MOF/NF was 614 A g–1 at 1.5 V vs RHE, which was approximately 6-fold higher than that of RuO2 (e). The corresponding specific activity (the current density normalized to the ECSA) of NiYCe-MOF/NF was 22.6 mA cm–2, which was 7 times higher than that of the commercial RuO2 catalyst. In contrast, Ni-MOF/NF had almost no catalytic activity toward the OER. As shown in f and Table S1, the as-prepared NiYCe-MOF/NF showed remarkable catalytic performance compared with state-of-the-art RuO2 and other recently reported OER electrocatalysts, suggesting that NiYCe-MOF/NF was a promising substitute for noble-metal electrocatalysts.

elements.content: As shown in a, the HER activity was first evaluated by LSV at 10 mV s–1; NiYCe-MOF/NF showed the highest HER activity with the lowest overpotential of 136 mV vs RHE, which was obviously better than those of Ni-MOF/NF (260 mV), NiY-MOF/NF (236 mV), and NiCe-MOF/NF (180 mV) at 10 mA cm–2. Moreover, the catalytic HER reaction kinetics were investigated by fitting the corresponding Tafel slopes to the LSV curves (b). The Tafel slope of NiYCe-MOF/NF was 74 mV dec–1, lower than those of Ni-MOF/NF (148 mV dec–1), NiY-MOF/NF (126 mV dec–1), and NiCe-MOF/NF (91 mV dec–1), indicating a more favorable electrocatalytic kinetics for the HER. The HER durability of NiYCe-MOF/NF was also tested by running 3000 consecutive LSV cycles and long-term chronopotentiometric tests over 100 h (c). In all, 3000 LSV cycles under a low-voltage window showed negligible current degeneration. Meanwhile, the chronopotentiometric test results showed that NiYCe-MOF/NF can be stably operated for more than 100 h with almost no attenuation.

elements.content: To evaluate the electrocatalytic stability of the constructed samples in practical applications, overall water-splitting measurements were performed in a two-electrode cell (d). As shown in e, NiYCe-MOF/NF exhibited excellent overall water-splitting performance with a total cell voltage of 1.54 V at 100 mA cm–2, which was obviously better than those of NiY-MOF/NF (1.68 V) and NiCe-MOF/NF (1.59 V). Furthermore, NiYCe-MOF/NF also exhibited impressive durability for the overall water-splitting reaction at different current densities from 10 to 150 mA cm–2. f shows that the water electrolysis voltage of NiYCe-MOF/NF can not only steadily increase with the increasing current density but also return to the initial state, suggesting fast recoverability. g shows that the current density can be kept stable at 300 mA cm–2 during a long-term stability test over 240 h; moreover, the surface morphology of NiYCe-MOF nanosheet arrays showed almost no change after a durability test for 240 h as shown in the insets. The chemical compositions of NiYCe-MOF were also deeply investigated after a 240 h long-term test (Figures S19 and S20). It can be seen that the morphology of NiYCe-MOF can still be well maintained, and the XRD pattern of NiYCe-MOF/NF after testing showed that the characteristic peaks were still tightly held without the formation of the other phase, demonstrating that the MOF structure effectively prevented the corrosion of the metal. The elemental mapping and EDS showed that C, O, Ni, Y, and Ce were uniformly distributed throughout the region. Additionally, NiYCe-MOF/NF also showed superior durability in alkaline solution after 3000 CV cycles (h). The above analysis results demonstrated the excellent stability of NiYCe-MOF/NF during the overall water-splitting process. The ultralow total cell voltage and excellent stability for overall water splitting may provide a potential candidate for practical industrial applications.

elements.content: In summary, we reported a facile method for the fabrication of ultrathin MOF nanosheet arrays doped with Y and Ce self-supported on NF to enhance performances toward the HER and OER. The doping of Y and Ce atoms into Ni-MOF has been proven to promote water-splitting performance by creating a bimetallic synergistic effect and constructing abundant active sites. The electronic structure of NiYCe-MOF/NF was controllably tailored by Y and Ce doping. When it was explored as an OER electrocatalyst, it achieved a low overpotential of 245 mV and a low Tafel slope of 65 mV dec–1 at 10 mA cm–2. Additionally, it also exhibited outstanding HER activity with a moderate overpotential of 136 mV at 10 mA cm–2. Notably, the required cell voltage was 1.54 V to achieve 100 mA cm–2 when NiYCe-MOF/NF was used as both the anode and cathode electrocatalyst for overall water splitting. Meanwhile, NiYCe-MOF/NF also exhibited superior stability during a 240 h durability test. The proposed doping of rare-earth elements into MOF catalysts to boost overall water splitting provides new insight into the design and synthesis of low-cost, highly efficient, and stable MOF catalysts for other electrocatalysis fields.

cln_elements.content:
The construction of low-cost, highly efficient, and stable electrocatalysts is a significant challenge for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Herein, we report a facile strategy to fabricate ultrathin metal–organic framework (MOF) nanosheet arrays doped with two rare-earth elements, Y and Ce, and self-supported on nickel foam (NF) to enhance the HER and OER performance by constructing abundant active sites and bimetallic synergistic effects. The NiYCe-MOF/NF features an ultrathin nanosheet array structure and is uniformly and richly codoped by Y and Ce. When it was explored as both the anode and cathode electrocatalysts for overall water splitting, it achieved 10 mA cm–2 at 136 and 245 mV for the HER and OER in an alkaline electrolyte, respectively. Notably, an extremely low cell voltage of 1.54 V was required to achieve 100 mA cm–2 in 1.0 M KOH solution, making it a promising substitute for noble-metal catalysts.

Herein, we report the synthesis of Y- and Ce-doped ultrathin MOF nanosheet array electrocatalysts by a simple hydrothermal method using Ni-MOF as a template. The obtained NiYCe-MOF/NF was employed as a bifunctional electrocatalyst to explore the overall water splitting. In particular, the structural characterizations verified that the doping of rare-earth atoms at the Ni sites induced electron transfer to the Ni sites. Benefiting from the unique electronic and structural features of the constructed catalyst, the resulting NiYCe-MOF/NF showed excellent electrochemical HER and OER activities with overpotentials of 136 and 245 mV at 10 mA cm–2, respectively, which are significantly better than those of previously reported Ni-MOF-based catalysts.

XANES and EXAFS were measured to further explore the chemical states of typical Ni-MOF and NiYCe-MOF using Ni foil, NiO, and Ni­(OH)2 as references. As shown in a, the peaks of the samples located at approximately 8349 eV in the pre-edge region can be attributed to the dipole-forbidden but quadrupole-allowed transition from 1s to 3d, which were equivalent to the NiO benchmark. The positions of the rising edges of the samples compared to the reference value of the Ni foil indicated that the oxidation state of Ni was between Ni0 and NiII. Meanwhile, the rising-edge positions of Ni-MOF were negatively shifted compared to those of NiO, while NiYCe-MOF showed a similar trend. This phenomenon indicated that some electrons were transferred to the site of Ni after the introduction of Y and Ce, which may be due to the rearrangement of electron distribution caused by the interaction of Ni with rare-earth elements. As presented in b, the FT-EXAFS intensities of all the corresponding peaks for the NiYCe-MOF were decreased relative to those of Ni foil, NiO, Ni­(OH)2, and Ni-MOF control samples, indicating an increase in the coordination number of the Ni atoms. The EXAFS spectra of Ni-MOF and NiYCe-MOF showed a main peak at 1.62 Å, corresponding to Ni–O coordination, which indicated that Ni ions were dominant in the oxidation state. The above results showed that the coordination number of the Ni–O shell remained nearly constant after Y and Ce codoping, suggesting a well-preserved stability structure. At the same time, the maximum intensities of Ni states in the WT contour map of Ni-MOF and NiYCe-MOF were also significantly different from those of Ni foil and NiO (c–f), suggesting that the Y and Ce heteroatoms were successfully doped into the Ni-MOF matrix. g shows that NiYCe-MOF exhibited a highly abundant porous structure along with the highest absorption capacity, resulting in the highest specific surface area (124.6 m2/g); additionally, the specific surface areas of Ni-MOF, NiCe-MOF, and NiYCe-MOF were 106.4, 112.0, and 94.2 m2/g, respectively (Figure S13). In addition, the porous structure of NiYCe-MOF further exhibited a hierarchical porous size, extending from nanometers to sub-micrometers, with an average pore size of 30 nm (see the inset in g). These results indicated that NiYCe-MOF contained a substantial number of mesopores, which favored the mass transfer process.

The electrocatalytic performances of the samples were evaluated in 1.0 M KOH solution with a typical system of commercial Pt/C (20 wt %) and RuO2 catalysts as benchmarks. The quantitative analysis data of doping elements and the amounts of catalyst loadings are detailed in Figured S14–S16 in the Supporting Information. A representative LSV test (a) shows that NiYCe-MOF/NF exhibited superior OER activity compared with Ni-MOF/NF, NiY-MOF/NF, and NiCe-MOF/NF. Even the OER performance of NiYCe-MOF/NF is significantly better than that of commercial RuO2. Likewise, the line-fitting Tafel plot of 65 mV dec–1 for NiYCe-MOF/NF in b was lower than those of Ni-MOF/NF, NiY-MOF/NF, NiCe-MOF/NF, and commercial RuO2, indicating the more effective reaction kinetics of NiYCe-MOF/NF for the OER. As shown in c, a chronopotentiometric test was employed to estimate the stability of NiYCe-MOF/NF. The retention rate of the initial catalytic activity can reach 94% after 100 h at 100 mA cm–2, while NiYCe-MOF/NF a suffered slight performance degradation (10%) at 200 mA cm–2. The above analysis results illustrated that NiYCe-MOF/NF possessed excellent stability in the long-term OER operation process. As shown in Figure S17, the EIS of the samples showed that NiYCe-MOF/NF exhibited a small polarization resistance and demonstrated faster catalytic kinetics and an enhanced electron transfer rate relative to Ni-MOF/NF, NiY-MOF/NF, and NiCe-MOF/NF due to the abundant active catalytic sites and the synergistic effect between different metal centers. In addition, the electrochemical active surface areas (ECSAs) were also calculated by measuring the Cdl values from CV curves (d and Figure S18). NiYCe-MOF/NF exhibited a Cdl value of nearly 36.5 mF cm–2, higher than those of Ni-MOF/NF (4.1 mF cm–2), NiY-MOF/NF (25.9 mF cm–2) and NiCe-MOF/NF electrodes (29.8 mF cm–2), indicating that NiYCe-MOF/NF was equipped with more active sites. The mass activity (the current density normalized to the mass) of NiYCe-MOF/NF was 614 A g–1 at 1.5 V vs RHE, which was approximately 6-fold higher than that of RuO2 (e). The corresponding specific activity (the current density normalized to the ECSA) of NiYCe-MOF/NF was 22.6 mA cm–2, which was 7 times higher than that of the commercial RuO2 catalyst. In contrast, Ni-MOF/NF had almost no catalytic activity toward the OER. As shown in f and Table S1, the as-prepared NiYCe-MOF/NF showed remarkable catalytic performance compared with state-of-the-art RuO2 and other recently reported OER electrocatalysts, suggesting that NiYCe-MOF/NF was a promising substitute for noble-metal electrocatalysts.

As shown in a, the HER activity was first evaluated by LSV at 10 mV s–1; NiYCe-MOF/NF showed the highest HER activity with the lowest overpotential of 136 mV vs RHE, which was obviously better than those of Ni-MOF/NF (260 mV), NiY-MOF/NF (236 mV), and NiCe-MOF/NF (180 mV) at 10 mA cm–2. Moreover, the catalytic HER reaction kinetics were investigated by fitting the corresponding Tafel slopes to the LSV curves (b). The Tafel slope of NiYCe-MOF/NF was 74 mV dec–1, lower than those of Ni-MOF/NF (148 mV dec–1), NiY-MOF/NF (126 mV dec–1), and NiCe-MOF/NF (91 mV dec–1), indicating a more favorable electrocatalytic kinetics for the HER. The HER durability of NiYCe-MOF/NF was also tested by running 3000 consecutive LSV cycles and long-term chronopotentiometric tests over 100 h (c). In all, 3000 LSV cycles under a low-voltage window showed negligible current degeneration. Meanwhile, the chronopotentiometric test results showed that NiYCe-MOF/NF can be stably operated for more than 100 h with almost no attenuation.

To evaluate the electrocatalytic stability of the constructed samples in practical applications, overall water-splitting measurements were performed in a two-electrode cell (d). As shown in e, NiYCe-MOF/NF exhibited excellent overall water-splitting performance with a total cell voltage of 1.54 V at 100 mA cm–2, which was obviously better than those of NiY-MOF/NF (1.68 V) and NiCe-MOF/NF (1.59 V). Furthermore, NiYCe-MOF/NF also exhibited impressive durability for the overall water-splitting reaction at different current densities from 10 to 150 mA cm–2. f shows that the water electrolysis voltage of NiYCe-MOF/NF can not only steadily increase with the increasing current density but also return to the initial state, suggesting fast recoverability. g shows that the current density can be kept stable at 300 mA cm–2 during a long-term stability test over 240 h; moreover, the surface morphology of NiYCe-MOF nanosheet arrays showed almost no change after a durability test for 240 h as shown in the insets. The chemical compositions of NiYCe-MOF were also deeply investigated after a 240 h long-term test (Figures S19 and S20). It can be seen that the morphology of NiYCe-MOF can still be well maintained, and the XRD pattern of NiYCe-MOF/NF after testing showed that the characteristic peaks were still tightly held without the formation of the other phase, demonstrating that the MOF structure effectively prevented the corrosion of the metal. The elemental mapping and EDS showed that C, O, Ni, Y, and Ce were uniformly distributed throughout the region. Additionally, NiYCe-MOF/NF also showed superior durability in alkaline solution after 3000 CV cycles (h). The above analysis results demonstrated the excellent stability of NiYCe-MOF/NF during the overall water-splitting process. The ultralow total cell voltage and excellent stability for overall water splitting may provide a potential candidate for practical industrial applications.

In summary, we reported a facile method for the fabrication of ultrathin MOF nanosheet arrays doped with Y and Ce self-supported on NF to enhance performances toward the HER and OER. The doping of Y and Ce atoms into Ni-MOF has been proven to promote water-splitting performance by creating a bimetallic synergistic effect and constructing abundant active sites. The electronic structure of NiYCe-MOF/NF was controllably tailored by Y and Ce doping. When it was explored as an OER electrocatalyst, it achieved a low overpotential of 245 mV and a low Tafel slope of 65 mV dec–1 at 10 mA cm–2. Additionally, it also exhibited outstanding HER activity with a moderate overpotential of 136 mV at 10 mA cm–2. Notably, the required cell voltage was 1.54 V to achieve 100 mA cm–2 when NiYCe-MOF/NF was used as both the anode and cathode electrocatalyst for overall water splitting. Meanwhile, NiYCe-MOF/NF also exhibited superior stability during a 240 h durability test. The proposed doping of rare-earth elements into MOF catalysts to boost overall water splitting provides new insight into the design and synthesis of low-cost, highly efficient, and stable MOF catalysts for other electrocatalysis fields.

As shown in a, the HER activity was first evaluated by LSV at 10 mV s-1; NiYCe-MOF/NF showed the highest HER activity with the lowest overpotential of 136 mV vs RHE, which was obviously better than those of Ni-MOF/NF (260 mV), NiY-MOF/NF (236 mV), and NiCe-MOF/NF (180 mV) at 10 mA cm-2. Moreover, the catalytic HER reaction kinetics were investigated by fitting the corresponding Tafel slopes to the LSV curves (b). The Tafel slope of NiYCe-MOF/NF was 74 mV dec-1, lower than those of Ni-MOF/NF (148 mV dec-1), NiY-MOF/NF (126 mV dec-1), and NiCe-MOF/NF (91 mV dec-1), indicating a more favorable electrocatalytic kinetics for the HER. The HER durability of NiYCe-MOF/NF was also tested by running 3000 consecutive LSV cycles and long-term chronopotentiometric tests over 100 h (c). In all, 3000 LSV cycles under a low-voltage window showed negligible current degeneration. Meanwhile, the chronopotentiometric test results showed that NiYCe-MOF/NF can be stably operated for more than 100 h with almost no attenuation.

To evaluate the electrocatalytic stability of the constructed samples in practical applications, overall water-splitting measurements were performed in a two-electrode cell (d). As shown in e, NiYCe-MOF/NF exhibited excellent overall water-splitting performance with a total cell voltage of 1.54 V at 100 mA cm-2, which was obviously better than those of NiY-MOF/NF (1.68 V) and NiCe-MOF/NF (1.59 V). Furthermore, NiYCe-MOF/NF also exhibited impressive durability for the overall water-splitting reaction at different current densities from 10 to 150 mA cm-2. f shows that the water electrolysis voltage of NiYCe-MOF/NF can not only steadily increase with the increasing current density but also return to the initial state, suggesting fast recoverability. g shows that the current density can be kept stable at 300 mA cm-2 during a long-term stability test over 240 h; moreover, the surface morphology of NiYCe-MOF nanosheet arrays showed almost no change after a durability test for 240 h as shown in the insets. The chemical compositions of NiYCe-MOF were also deeply investigated after a 240 h long-term test (Figures S19 and S20). It can be seen that the morphology of NiYCe-MOF can still be well maintained, and the XRD pattern of NiYCe-MOF/NF after testing showed that the characteristic peaks were still tightly held without the formation of the other phase, demonstrating that the MOF structure effectively prevented the corrosion of the metal. The elemental mapping and EDS showed that C, O, Ni, Y, and Ce were uniformly distributed throughout the region. Additionally, NiYCe-MOF/NF also showed superior durability in alkaline solution after 3000 CV cycles (h). The above analysis results demonstrated the excellent stability of NiYCe-MOF/NF during the overall water-splitting process. The ultralow total cell voltage and excellent stability for overall water splitting may provide a potential candidate for practical industrial applications.

In summary, we reported a facile method for the fabrication of ultrathin MOF nanosheet arrays doped with Y and Ce self-supported on NF to enhance performances toward the HER and OER. The doping of Y and Ce atoms into Ni-MOF has been proven to promote water-splitting performance by creating a bimetallic synergistic effect and constructing abundant active sites. The electronic structure of NiYCe-MOF/NF was controllably tailored by Y and Ce doping. When it was explored as an OER electrocatalyst, it achieved a low overpotential of 245 mV and a low Tafel slope of 65 mV dec-1 at 10 mA cm-2. Additionally, it also exhibited outstanding HER activity with a moderate overpotential of 136 mV at 10 mA cm-2. Notably, the required cell voltage was 1.54 V to achieve 100 mA cm-2 when NiYCe-MOF/NF was used as both the anode and cathode electrocatalyst for overall water splitting. Meanwhile, NiYCe-MOF/NF also exhibited superior stability during a 240 h durability test. The proposed doping of rare-earth elements into MOF catalysts to boost overall water splitting provides new insight into the design and synthesis of low-cost, highly efficient, and stable MOF catalysts for other electrocatalysis fields.
